abstract: Bank of New York Mellon’s chief executive, Robert Kelly, is the front-runner to succeed retiring Bank of America chief Kenneth Lewis, but compensation issues could get in the way of a deal, The Wall Street Journal reported.
snippet: Bank of New York Mellon’s chief executive, Robert Kelly, is the front-runner to succeed retiring Bank of America chief Kenneth Lewis, but compensation issues could get in the way of a deal, The Wall Street Journal reported.
lead_paragraph: Bank of New York Mellon‘s chief executive, Robert Kelly, is the front-runner to succeed the retiring Bank of America chief Kenneth D. Lewis, but compensation issues could get in the way of a deal, The Wall Street Journal reported, citing people familiar with the situation.

headline.main: N.Y. Mellon Chief Said to Be in Lead for BofA Post

abstract: President Obama talked with the executives that he termed “fat cats” on Monday, asking the chiefs of the nation’s biggest banks to the White House to press them to help speed the economic recovery by providing more loans to small businesses and homeowners.
snippet: President Obama talked with the executives that he termed “fat cats” on Monday, asking the chiefs of the nation’s biggest banks to the White House to press them to help speed the economic recovery by providing more loans to small businesses and ho...
lead_paragraph: President Obama talked with the executives that he termed “fat cats” on Monday, asking the chiefs of the nation’s biggest banks to the White House to press them to help speed the economic recovery by providing more loans to small businesses and homeowners, The New York Times’s Helene Cooper reported.

headline.main: Weather Keeps Some Bankers Away From Obama Talk

abstract: Bank of New York Mellon’s chief executive, Robert P. Kelly, has again told employees in an internal memo obtained by DealBook that he’s staying, despite entreaties from “another bank” (read: Bank of America).
snippet: Bank of New York Mellon’s chief executive, Robert P. Kelly, has again told employees in an internal memo obtained by DealBook that he’s staying, despite entreaties from “another bank” (read: Bank of America).
lead_paragraph: He’s said it before, and he’s saying it again: Robert P. Kelly is staying at Bank of New York Mellon as its chief executive.
